question:
You are a math expert. When you respond, respond only with the Solution of the final Problem, thinking step by step. At the end of the Solution, when you give your final answer, write it in the form 'Final Answer: \\boxed{$answer$}. I hope it is correct.'
For how many positive integral values of $a$ is it true that $x = 2$ is the only positive integer solution of the system of inequalities $$
\begin{cases}
2x>3x-3\\
3x-a>-6
\end{cases}
$$
inference:
$$
\begin{aligned}
2x &>3x-3\\
\Rightarrow\qquad 3 &< x\\
\end{aligned}
$$

$$
\begin{aligned}
3x-a &>-6\\
\Rightarrow\qquad a &< 3x+6\\
\Rightarrow\qquad a &< 3(3)+6=15
\end{aligned}
$$

So, the answer is 15.

Final Answer: \boxed{15}. I hope it is correct.
ground_truth: If we start by looking at the first inequality, we see it is equivalent to $3>x,$ so the only possible positive integers $x$ could be are $x=1$ or $x=2.$ Now, looking at the second equation, if $x=2$ we have $$3(2)-a>-6 \Rightarrow 12>a$$ If $x=1,$ then $$3(1)-a>-6 \Rightarrow 9>a.$$ We want $x=2$ to be the only solution. Thus, we must choose $a=9,$ $10,$ $11.$ This is $\boxed{3}$ possible values.

\begin{aligned}
2x &>3x-3\\
\Rightarrow\qquad 3 &< x\\
\end{aligned}
$$

\begin{aligned}

\Rightarrow\qquad a &< 3(3)+6=15

So, the answer is 15.

Final Answer: \boxed{15}. I hope it is correct.

Thus, we must choose $a=9,$ $10,$ $11.$ This is $\boxed{3}$ possible values.
